column1: All The Science You Need To Make Your COVID-19 Decisions
column3: _If there’s one thing we’ve learned since March 2020, it’s that pandemics are all about hard decisions._ It’s hard to keep track of the information that helps us make those choices — let alone notice or remember when new science and expert recommendations come along. column1: The Fight Over COVID-19 Vaccine Mandates Is Coming To Kids Next
column3: It took a small town chiropractor named Charles Brown to help vaccinate millions of kids for decades to come — all because he didn’t want to vaccinate his own. It was 1979 in Houston, Mississippi, and Brown needed to enroll his 6-year-old son in school. But state law required the boy to be vaccinated against […]

column1: Americans Want The Government To Act On Climate Change. What’s The Hold-Up?
column3: Welcome to Pollapalooza, our weekly polling roundup. As President Biden and other Democrats work to pass an omnibus budget bill, members of the party are at odds over the topline spending number, with figures ranging between $1.5 trillion to $3.5 trillion. column1: Why Past Hurricane Seasons Don’t Tell Us Much About The Future
column3: Nearly two months are left in the Atlantic hurricane season, and so far 20 named storms have formed in the Atlantic basin. That includes Hurricanes Henri and Ida, which brought torrential rain and winds up to 75 and 150 miles per hour, respectively. After last year’s record-high 31 named storms and this year’s above-average season, […]

column1: Where Breitbart’s False Claim That Democrats Want Republicans To Stay Unvaccinated Came From
column3: This is the latest edition of our column that excavates the origins of public figures’ factually dubious comments. We explain what their claims are referring to, the evidence (or lack thereof) behind them and where they sprang from in the first place. column1: Republicans Aren’t New To The Anti-Vaxx Movement
column3: At first glance, Melissa seems to meet all the criteria of the “crunchy granola” type. column1: Vaccines Mandates Work, But They’re Messy
column3: On Thursday, President Biden announced a new Labor Department rule that would require all employers with more than 100 employees to make sure workers get fully vaccinated or test negative for COVID-19 once a week. It’s the federal government’s most aggressive step yet toward a vaccine mandate, and it’s one that comes fraught with legal […]

column1: The U.S. Is Relying On Other Countries’ Data To Make Its Booster Shot Decisions
column3: One Thursday in October, the Food and Drug Administration’s vaccine advisory committee gathered to discuss booster shots for Moderna and Johnson & Johnson’s COVID-19 vaccines. Yet one of the first presentations wasn’t given by Americans — it featured scientists from Israel’s Ministry of Health and Weizmann Institute. column1: How Are Kids Handling The Pandemic? We Asked Them.
column3: After an excruciating wait for many families, children ages 5 and older can now be vaccinated against COVID-19. column1: Why Many Americans Underestimate Who Is Most Concerned About The Environment
